To obtain a valid Snowflake access token for use with the Snowflake Web API, you can use one of several authentication methods supported by Snowflake. Here's an overview of the most common authentication methods:

1. Username and password: You can authenticate with Snowflake by providing your Snowflake account username and password. To obtain a token using this method, you can use the Snowflake Authentication API. Here's an example cURL command:
```vbnet
curl -X POST \
  'https://<ACCOUNT_NAME>.snowflakecomputing.com/session/v1/login-request?warehouse=<WAREHOUSE>&database=<DATABASE>&schema=<SCHEMA>&role=<ROLE>' \
  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  -d '{
        "data": {
            "LOGIN_NAME": "<USERNAME>",
            "PASSWORD": "<PASSWORD>",
            "ACCOUNT_NAME": "<ACCOUNT_NAME>"
        }
    }'
```
In this example, you'll need to replace `<ACCOUNT_NAME>`, `<USERNAME>`, and `<PASSWORD>` with your Snowflake account credentials, and `<WAREHOUSE>`, `<DATABASE>`, `<SCHEMA>`, and `<ROLE>` with the names of the warehouse, database, schema, and role you want to use for the session. The Snowflake Authentication API will return a JSON object containing a valid access token that you can use with the Snowflake Web API.

1. External OAuth: You can also authenticate with Snowflake using an external OAuth provider, such as Okta, Azure AD, or Google. To use this method, you'll need to configure your Snowflake account to use external OAuth and set up an OAuth connection with your provider. Once you've done this, you can obtain an access token from your provider and use it to authenticate with Snowflake.
2. SSO (Single Sign-On): If your organization uses SSO for Snowflake, you can authenticate with Snowflake using your SSO provider. To do this, you'll need to configure your Snowflake account to use SSO and set up a trust relationship between Snowflake and your SSO provider. Once you've done this, you can authenticate with Snowflake by logging in to your SSO provider.

Note that the specific steps required to obtain a Snowflake access token will depend on the authentication method you're using and the tools and libraries you're working with. Snowflake provides detailed documentation and sample code for each authentication method, which you can find in the Snowflake documentation.
